seg.seg: ... to come together with the community in listening to the law and in ... [1b] All these obstacles ... [1c]
... and you have come together with the right time of an omniscient one. [1d] Those who lead to virtue ... [2a]
Mit der Wirkungszeit eines Allerkenners bist auch du zusammengekommen.
You also came together with the time of an Omniscient's ministry.
... you have the insight and the desire for virtue. [2b] That much [you] do not ... precisely this ... in this way ... [2c]
... 2[d] If he has not come together with the three excellent jewels [3a]
... he will be to be turned in ... [3c] Even if he makes a mistake than his ... is not ... [3d]
... [4a] He commits evil for himself and for others ... only away. [4b]
... like a ... if he falls in a pit, ... wearing ... 4[d] One should not trust an untrustworthy [person] ... [5a]
... [5b] This light and unsteady mind, untamable, ... (is led?) to virtue ... [5c]

p.note: It seems that the leaf contains strophes in only one metre, which seems to be 4 x 5 ¦ 7 ¦ 5, or sometimes perhaps also 4 x 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5. This metre, and the alternation between 5 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 and 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5, is typical of niṣkramānt (19; 339). The rarer subdivision 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5 may be found in pādas 2a and 4b (if enclitic no rather belongs before the break). Apparently the strophe number 1 is missing after kamtsatai twe no ṣp : in a2. According to the number of akṣaras estimated to be missing on the left, the leaf started with this poem; pāda 1a may have been preceded by an indication of the tune, e.g. || niṣkramāntne ||. However, the 5th strophe must have continued on a second leaf and perhaps the poem was much longer. – pāda missing completely – [1a] (17 syllables missing) [a1]/// (l)ñ(e)ne ¦ pelaikne klyauṣalñene ¦ sāṅkämpa ṣpä śamtsi : [1b] (3 syllables missing) toṃ po pkänte[a2](nma) ¦ [1c] (13 syllables missing) /// poyśiññai ekṣalympa ¦ kamtsatai twe no ṣp : [1d] (6 syllables missing) kartseścä aśeñcañ ¦ [2a] (11 syllables missing) [a3] /// pilko star-ca ¦ ñyās ṣpä kartseśco : [2b] (8 syllables missing) tuk māka mā nai ¦ ttauwak te-yä(knesa) [2c] (6 syllables missing) [a4]/// -tsi 2 (16 syllables missing) ente krui śpālme ¦ toṃ tarya nomyentampa ¦ mā ke(kamu) [3a] (2 syllables missing) – pāda missing completely – [3b] (17 syllables missing) [b1]/// -ne spārtatsi tākaṃ : [3c] (11 syllables missing) su krui ra triśäṃ ¦ ot mā cwi n· [3d] (8 syllables missing) [b2] /// -ṣträ : [4a] (16 syllables missing) yolo yamaṣän ¦ no añmatse śle =lyeṅkäts ¦ ka ts· p·st [4b] (2 syllables missing) [b3] – pāda missing completely – [4c] (17 syllables missing) /// (ra)mtä kārene klāyä ¦ kwri auswa nno tsa 4 (6 syllables missing) empakwaccai mā ¦ pkwaly(e) – [5a] (9 syllables missing) [b4]/// – ske : [5b] (15 syllables missing) laṅkce slakareṃ ¦ ceṃ palsko āyātaicce ¦ kartseś pä – [5c]

The upper and lower margins of the fragment are preserved, and most probably the right margin in lines a1-2 and b3-4 as well. Approximately 1 akṣara is missing on the right of lines a3 and b2, and approximately 5 akṣaras are missing on the right of lines a4 and b1. According to the metre (which is not absolutely certain, see the discussion below), 19-21 syllables are missing on the left in the lines with the string hole space (apparently a2, a3, and b2), and 24-25 are missing in the other lines (a4, b1, b3, b4, and most probably also a1). Since lines a1, a2, b3, and b4 contain 19-21 akṣaras, and the 24-25 missing syllables on the left will make about 28 akṣaras, the original width of the leaf may have been close to 50 akṣaras or approximately 40 cms.
According to 183 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved".

sāṅkämpa ṣpä śamtsi: 183 restored sāṅkämpa (ṣe) ṣpä śamtsi. Indeed, there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara after sāṅkämpa (not with 183sāṅkämpā!), but on the evidence of āyātaicce b4 no text is missing and the hole must have been there already at the time the manuscript was written. Although 'come together' is often "com. + eṣe + kəm-", it is here clearly just "com. + kəm-"; cf. ekṣalympa kamtsatai a2.
śpālme: for śpālmeṃ. Pace 184, śpālme is not a variant, but simply a mistake.

mā ke(kamu): 183 restored mā ke(kenusa), but the first akṣara cannot have e-vocalism according to the manuscript traces (also, his translation as 'attained' is not correct and does not fit his restoration). In addition, kekenu is always construed with a perl., i.e. 'provided with', whereas we have here a com. The construction com. + kekamu is also found in b2. One further syllable is required by the metre, but there is no reason to restore a nom.sg.f. kekamusa; rather, one might think of a particle like ṣpä or no.
spārtatsi tākaṃ: this construction is unclear and the meaning is obscure.

/// (ra)mtä kārene klāyä kwri auswa nno tsa: this passage is obscure. With 184, klāyä is probably to be corrected into klāyaṃ, but especially auswa nno tsa is difficult. In any case, 71's reading kārene klāyaṃ kwri auswann ot sa "Wenn sie (?) in die Grube fällt, dann schreit (?) sie" is not convincing either.

āyātaicce: according to the context, the word seems complete, but there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara between ā and yātaicce that was presumably already there when the manuscript was written.

laṅkce slakareṃ ceṃ palsko āyātaicce: cf. Uv.31.8a-b spandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ durakṣyaṃ durnivāraṇam (410) 'The mind that is trembling and unsteady, difficult to guard and difficult to restrain' (125).

[[Broomhead I]] has notes on p. 184 and translates on pp. 183-184:

a1 [And] with ... ing ... [and] with listening to the dharma, to go in company with the community: All these obstacles ...

a2 You have indeed also come at the epoch of the Buddha: those who lead to salvation ...

a3 You have the insight and the desire for salvation. Even that much [and] not even she [is] in this way ...

a4 ... to ...: 2. If these three most excellent jewels [have] not been attained ...

b1 It will be to proceed. Also if this one should stumble, then he is not full.

b2 [is desired]. He commits evil himself and also with others ...

b3 If she should fall into a pit, then she will cry out: one should never put one's trust in an unreliable one.

b4 [alone]. It is light this weak spirit [and is] unsubdued for [the purpose of] salvation. The spirit ...

Approximately 1 akṣara is missing on the right of lines a3 and b2, and approximately 5 akṣaras are missing on the right of lines a4 and b1. According to [[Broomhead I]]: 183 "[w]ritten in medium ductus, and clearly preserved".

Text notes:

a1 sāṅkämpa ṣpä śamtsi: [[Broomhead I]]: 183 restored sāṅkämpa (ṣe) ṣpä śamtsi. Indeed, there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara after sāṅkämpa (not with [[Broomhead I]]: 183 sāṅkämpā!), but on the evidence of āyātaicce b4 no text is missing and the hole must have been there already at the time the manuscript was written. Although 'come together' is often "com. + eṣe + kəm-", it is here clearly just "com. + kəm-"; cf. ekṣalympa kamtsatai a2.
a3 star-ca: for star-cä
a3 nomyentampa: for naumyentampa.
a4 śpālme: for śpālmeṃ. Pace [[Broomhead I]]: 184, śpālme is not a variant, but simply a mistake.
a4 mā ke(kamu): [[Broomhead I]]: 183 restored mā ke(kenusa), but the first akṣara cannot have e-vocalism according to the manuscript traces (also, his translation as 'attained' is not correct and does not fit his restoration). In addition, kekenu is always construed with a perl., i.e. 'provided with', whereas we have here a com. The construction com. + kekamu is also found in [[THT 304]] b2. One further syllable is required by the metre, but there is no reason to restore a nom.sg.f. kekamusa; rather, one might think of a particle like ṣpä or no.
b1 spārtatsi tākaṃ: this construction is unclear and the meaning is obscure.
b3 /// (ra)mtä kārene klāyä kwri auswa nno tsa: this passage is obscure. With [[Broomhead I]]: 184, klāyä is probably to be corrected into klāyaṃ, but especially auswa nno tsa is difficult. In any case, [[Krause, WTG]]: 71's reading kārene klāyaṃ kwri auswann ot sa "Wenn sie (?) in die Grube fällt, dann schreit (?) sie" is not convincing either.
b4 āyātaicce: according to the context, the word seems complete, but there is a hole of the size of approximately one akṣara between ā and yātaicce that was presumably already there when the manuscript was written.
b4 laṅkce slakareṃ ceṃ palsko āyātaicce: cf. Uv.31.8a-b spandanaṃ capalaṃ cittaṃ durakṣyaṃ durnivāraṇam ([[Bernhard 1965]]: 410) 'The mind that is trembling and unsteady, difficult to guard and difficult to restrain' ([[Hahn 2007]]: 125).

Metrical analysis:

It seems that the leaf contains strophes in only one metre, which seems to be 4 x 5 ¦ 7 ¦ 5, or sometimes perhaps also 4 x 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5. This metre, and the alternation between 5 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 and 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5, is typical of niṣkramānt ([[TochSprR(B) II]]: 19; [[Adams, DoT]]: 339). The rarer subdivision 6 ¦ 6 ¦ 5 may be found in pādas 2a and 4b (if enclitic no rather belongs before the break). Apparently the strophe number 1 is missing after kamtsatai twe no ṣp : in a2. According to the number of akṣaras estimated to be missing on the left, the leaf started with this poem; pāda 1a may have been preceded by an indication of the tune, e.g. || niṣkramāntne ||. However, the 5th strophe must have continued on a second leaf and perhaps the poem was much longer.
